British Airways will commence a bi-weekly service linking Manchester with the Canadian city this autumn. The carrier announced the launch of the route after experimenting with several direct flights to Canada in past autumns. The service is scheduled to run from 15 September to 20 December this year, utilizing British Airways' Boeing 787 Dreamliner aircraft. Adam Carson, Managing Director of British Airways, expressed: "We're thrilled to introduce a continuous flight to Toronto this autumn, made possible by the positive response and encouragement we've encountered following our temporary flights to Canada. This is excellent news for travelers, offering them more options for direct flights from Manchester to this beloved destination." Manchester Airport has expressed enthusiasm for the new connection. Aviation Director Alyson Cavanagh stated: "Toronto draws millions of tourists annually, and this marks the first instance Manchester will host a regular service to what is often dubbed the cultural capital of Canada. British Airways’ decision to launch a bi-weekly service to Toronto during the 2023 autumn season is not only tremendous for Manchester Airport and our passengers but also enhances our comprehensive range of long-distance flights." In addition, the airline announced a new flight route to Egypt, providing service twice a week during the autumn of 2023.

Michael Johnson is accused of fabricating and possessing a hazardous material with the motive of threatening public safety, yet during proceedings at the Central Criminal Court, he confessed to carrying out a false bomb threat. 
The legal representatives argued that Johnson designed the makeshift explosive with the intention for it to detonate and compromise the safety of commuters on the Northern Line subway. 
The attorneys stated that the homemade explosive was equipped with nails to serve as shrapnel.
Elizabeth Grant QC, representing the state, explained that the inclusion of nails aimed to amplify the lethal potential of the bomb.
At the trial's commencement, Ms. Grant revealed that the accused had initially informed the police that his homemade device was supposed to emit only smoke upon activation.
Nevertheless, Johnson later admitted to incorporating nails to mimic an authentic explosive, hoping to cause a train delay and garner media attention, Ms. Grant added.
Testimonies disclosed that the device was discovered by two riders after Johnson exited at King's Cross station in November.
The commuters gave it to operator James Warren, who first mistook it for a forgotten item but realized its dangerous nature as he proceeded to Camden Town upon noticing wires protruding from a clock, it was reported.
It was shared in court that the defendant had relocated to Hackney in East London with his mother from Exeter, Devon, and was pursuing a cybersecurity degree at the University of East London.
Johnson has been diagnosed with Asperger's Syndrome, now referred to as Autism Spectrum Disorder, and displays a profound fascination with weaponry, which could be related to his condition, the court learned.
The court was informed of the following evidence collected by officials:
Johnson disclosed to officers his upbringing as a Christian, yet he exhibited an interest in Buddhism, which he believed to be "more genuine".
Though he occasionally engaged in Buddhist practices, like meditation, especially during mornings if convenient, he did not advocate radical views, the court was briefed.
Ms. Grant remarked that on the incident day, Johnson had activated the bomb's timer while transitioning at Camden Town station.
Meanwhile, Johnson returned to his university at Stratford, searching for any emerging reports concerning the event once he reached home that evening.
The trial is ongoing.

Southampton City Council discussed the £300m Harbour Gateway project, which received over 200 objections.
The project proposes the construction of 2,000 residential units, including a secondary school, retirement community, local shopping complex, and public gardens on the western outskirts of the city.
The urban development board had a split vote, with six members supporting, six opposing, and the deciding vote cast by the board's president in support.
Opponents in attendance voiced their disapproval with cries of "betrayal" as the outcome was announced.
The project covers 220 hectares (543 acres) and stands as the most substantial proposal ever put before the council.
The project developers, Harborfront Ventures, claim it will substantially stimulate the city economy, potentially creating more than 5,000 employment opportunities.
Lead planner, Helen Jacobs, commented, "This is a watershed moment. We now shoulder the great duty of actualizing the employment figures pledged.
"For a transformative initiative of this scale, one that's pivotal for Southampton's revitalization, there were few viable alternatives.
"Our wish is that with planning permission in hand, people will recognize the value of our proposal – including the significant economic injection into Southampton."
However, resistance surfaced from local conservation groups and nature enthusiasts concerned over the implications for regional green spaces and wildlife.
Independent Southampton councillor, Marcus Penn, who resisted the scheme, expressed anxieties about anticipated traffic increases and whether the promised advantages will materialize.
"With the decision hinging on a tie-breaker and the justifications for deviating from the city's plan appearing weak, it’s probable that the residents would welcome a review of this decision by the national planning authority," he stated.

In 2013, Google announced the acquisition of the high-fidelity sensor technology company, WIMM Labs, to bolster its wearable technology segment, reportedly for an undisclosed amount. The financial specifics of the transaction were not shared, but it's speculated that Google aimed to significantly enhance its footprint in the smartwatch market with this move. WIMM Labs' technology was expected to be integrated into Google's smartwatch projects.

WIMM Labs had developed the WIMM One, a pioneering smartwatch platform that emphasized micro-apps and provided developers with a kit to create wearable applications. Despite the WIMM One not achieving massive commercial success, its approach to wearable technology was considered innovative for its time. Google's acquisition included the WIMM Labs' intellectual property, the team of engineers, and the expertise they brought to wearable technology development.

The move by Google was seen as a strategic effort to expand its ecosystem into wearable devices, especially as competition intensified from Apple's WatchOS and Samsung's Tizen-based watches. Industry analysts, like John Doe from TechAnalysis, viewed Google's acquisition of WIMM Labs as a potential game-changer for the future of Android-based wearable devices. Doe suggested that integrating WIMM's technology could make Google's wearables more user-friendly and feature-rich, underscoring the growing importance of software innovation in creating differentiated user experiences.

Google's leap into the wearable market with the acquisition of WIMM Labs was paralleled by its efforts to diversify its hardware offerings, as evidenced by the launch of the Google Glass Explorer Edition around the same time. The acquisition signified Google's commitment to being at the forefront of the rapidly evolving wearable technology landscape.

Examinations of three pairs of spectacles at the National Archives revealed significant worsening of the writer's vision. During that era, toxic substances like mercury were commonly included in treatments that Dickens, afflicted by gout, might have used. Experts at the archives think such exposure could have played a role in his premature demise at age 58. The author, who resided in London, passed away on 9 June 1870, and the reasons behind his death have long been debated.

The spectacles, stored in the desk where the "Great Expectations" author wrote, were assessed with a mobile optical device brought to the archives to evaluate the lens strength, which has remarkably remained intact over the years. The findings indicated a progressive increase in lens strength from +2.00 in each eye in the initial pair to +4.50 and +4.75 in the last pair, suggesting severe difficulties in reading or writing near his end.

National Archives curator Lucy Jennings remarked: "The thought that he might have been unintentionally poisoned with a toxic metal like mercury is plausible. We are now aware that mercury poisoning can lead to severe visual impairment. Mercury was frequently used in medications for various ailments, including possibly for gout, a condition known to affect Charles Dickens."

It remains unclear whether Dickens personally selected or was prescribed these spectacles, which were made from genuine shell and crystal. The National Archives is now reaching out to eye care specialists to discuss this new hypothesis.

Archbishop Justin Welby announced the decision following a summit with primates of the Anglican Communion in Canterbury.
In England, legislation enacted in 1928 authorized the fixing of Easter Sunday on the first Sunday after the second Saturday in April.
This legislation has never been implemented, so Easter's date continues to fluctuate according to lunar cycles.
Easter, the paramount Christian celebration, commemorates the resurrection of Jesus Christ after his crucifixion on Good Friday.
Archbishop Welby mentioned ongoing discussions with Pope Francis, Coptic Pope Tawadros II, and the Orthodox church’s leader Patriarch Bartholomew.
Welby expressed hope that the change could occur within the next five to ten years.
“I hope to see it realized before my retirement,” he stated, though he acknowledged that the first effort to establish a fixed date was made in the 10th Century.
An Anglican representative disclosed to the BBC that there have been 15 attempts to standardize the Easter date since that initial attempt.
Typically, Easter occurs on the first Sunday following the first ecclesiastical full moon after the spring equinox, which allows for celebration dates between March 22 and April 25.
The Orthodox church, however, adheres to the Julian calendar and consequently celebrates Easter later than Western Christian churches.
In 1990, the Vatican endorsed a motion to set a fixed date for Easter, contingent upon consensus among different Christian denominations and national governments, but this agreement has yet to be finalized.

The firm conducts a monthly analysis of companies, observing variables such as new contracts, workforce numbers, and international trade. The most recent summary for May indicated a slight worsening of corporate conditions, with production and new contracts decreasing after a rise in April. This marks the fifth decline in business operations in the past six months. Lagan Bank’s lead economist, Simon Carter, mentioned that Northern Ireland’s slight reduction in commercial sector activity stands in contrast to expansions observed in all other regions of the UK. The industrial sector remained a highlight, with increases in production and new contracts reaching a peak not seen for the past seven months, propelled by market needs in Great Britain. Conversely, Northern Irish shop owners noted the most significant drop in retail revenues since June 2013, and the construction industry experienced its biggest decline in commercial activity in over two years. Mr. Carter noted that despite the downturn indicated by these findings, businesses are still managing to expand their workforce. “In spite of the challenges and weak demand, local enterprises observed a surge in employment in May, the highest in eight months. There was job growth reported in all industries except construction,” he noted. In his future outlook, he mentioned that the specifics of the new Conservative government’s budgetary strategies and economic policies “will impact every sector of the economy, both governmental and private”.

The Grand Opera House was jubilantly hosting the debut night of "The Comedy of Errors" on Friday evening. However, patrons were abruptly ushered out when a burst pipe caused a deluge, interrupting the show.

The opera house manager, Emily Clarke, announced that the venue had been promptly cleared of water and the performance scheduled for Saturday evening would proceed without issue.

Jack Martin, who witnessed the evacuation while at the venue, remarked, "Water started cascading over the steps towards the orchestra pit."

The production, staged by the Grand Theatre Company, is part of a seven-week event commemorating 175 years of theatrical history in the city of York.

The incident occurred amid torrential downpours on Friday, which similarly unleashed chaos in Manchester, where several individuals were caught in vehicles due to the sudden flooding.

Ms. Clarke commented: "We've dealt with minor leaks in the past, given the building's age of 125 years, but we've never seen anything of this magnitude.”

Maggie Townsend attended the production with her family. She recounted, "The storm was terrifying – you could make out the sound of the storm overhead. Out of nowhere, we noticed the audience in the lower boxes rising to leave, and swiftly after, we were all exiting the building."

The group has now established a new encampment around three-quarters of a mile distant, in Liberty Park.

A number of protestors began to voluntarily dismantle their tents and belongings, departing without incident, while a faction stood their ground.

Several items thought to be aircraft wreckage were retrieved by civilians and subsequently transported to Canada for examination.
Transport Minister Marc Garneau commented that the discoveries align with predictive drift patterns indicating the path debris from the lost aircraft could have followed via sea currents.
Flight AC423 disappeared in May 2017 carrying 242 individuals.
The aircraft was en route from Toronto to London and is presumed to have plummeted into the North Atlantic Ocean after straying from its planned route.
What happened to the aircraft, along with its passengers and crew, remains an unsolved enigma in the history of aviation.
Up to this point, the only confirmed fragment of the aircraft found is a part of the tail known as the vertical stabilizer, discovered on the shores of Ireland.
One piece of wreckage recovered off the coast of Iceland was located by a Canadian volunteer in early March, while another was spotted in November by a tourist from France on a beach in Greenland.
Minister Garneau announced that the investigative team has completed their analysis of the found items and determined that both are likely from an Air Canada Airbus A320.
"The examination results strongly suggest the wreckage can be traced back to AC423," he stated.
He mentioned this indicates the ongoing, intensive underwater search operation in the northern Atlantic Ocean, headed by Canada, is likely targeting the correct region.
The international search effort, with assistance from the UK and France, involves deep-sea exploration in an effort to find the plane's remains, with vast portions of the seabed yet to be charted.
Garneau mentioned that the search is ongoing, with roughly 30,000 sq km (12,000 sq miles) left to explore.
"Our commitment remains to finalize this search and we maintain hope that the aircraft will be located."
However, the participating nations have made it clear that unless substantial new evidence emerges, they will conclude the search once the designated area has been thoroughly investigated. The mission is anticipated to finish in the forthcoming season.

The Unite union is announcing plans for additional strike action in the continuing conflict with Northern Rail regarding the issue of automated ticket barriers.
The Conservative Party has called on Grant Shapps to intervene and encourage discussions to break the deadlock.
The Department for Transport stated that the Secretary of State has been actively involved with both parties in efforts to resolve the disagreement.
Unite intends to carry out two more strikes lasting 24 hours each, set for Wednesday, 17th and 24th August, following unsuccessful negotiations through the mediation service Acas.
The Conservative transport spokesperson, Chris Loder, remarked: "Rail travelers have already suffered enough disruption this year owing to upgrade works at the Bank station and technical issues with the London Underground leading to service interruptions and cancellations.
"The new Labour transport secretary has declared solving the conflict on Northern Rail a significant priority. The current government needs to take the legitimate grievances of Northern Rail employees seriously and handle this matter appropriately."
Unite is against the push for more automated ticket barriers and argues that station staff should manage them, saying this approach is more secure.
However, Northern Rail has reported that in over 70% of stations, ticket barriers are already managed effectively by technology, and they promise that there will always be staff available to provide assistance to travelers when necessary.
A Department for Transport spokesperson stated: "The goal is to see these strikes come to an end, with the commuting public being the ones who would benefit the most.
"The Secretary of State for Transport and department officials have continued to be part of discussions with the aim of reaching a resolution, which we believe is still achievable through constructive dialog.
"In light of this, we urge both sides to reconvene and engage with each other to put an end to the industrial action.
"The government's emergency response team has been convened several times since the disruptions began to ensure strategic planning and backup procedures are in place to reduce the impact on commuters."
The Department for Transport has been reassured by Northern Rail that they expect to maintain normal operations for up to 85% of their services this coming Wednesday.
Travelers are encouraged to visit Northern Rail's strike information web page for the latest travel updates before setting out.

Pastor Jacob Marley informed a labor court that he had recited the scriptures at HM Prison Oakhill in Oxfordshire in 2016. He asserted that some of the inmates who identified as bisexual had lodged complaints, claiming his termination was discriminatory. His litigation against the ministry of corrections proceeds.

Pastor Marley, 46, a licenced Baptist preacher residing in Milton Keynes, was employed as a vocational training coordinator at the correctional facility located close to Witney. Since 2013, he had voluntarily led prayer sessions biweekly. At the hearing in Oxford, he mentioned he primarily emphasized on biblical teachings concerning redemption and forgiveness.

He pointed out that the scripture under scrutiny was Romans Chapter 1 Verses 26-28 which incorporates phrases like "men committed shameful acts with other men, and received in themselves the due penalty for their error." He disclosed he delivered this sermon on July 10, 2016.

Mr. Marley later learned that a bisexual inmate had voiced dissatisfaction or distress, leading to what he described as "a strategic effort" to bar him from leading further religious services. "I am afraid and convinced that reshaping the Christian doctrine to conform to current societal beliefs about sexuality is not justified," he expressed during the tribunal.

He recounted being informed that he could not volunteer for the religious gatherings anymore, followed by subsequent grievances regarding his conduct in vocational training. He was then required to appear at a disciplinary meeting after being accused in writing of making "bigoted remarks."

The independent auditor on border control stated that the Department of Homeland Security must implement substantial improvements regarding "expired visas" - individuals whose authorization to remain in the country has expired. 
Robert Wells stated that failing to address this issue could "erode trust among the population."
Border Control Chief Lisa Fortwright mentioned that there is potential for further enhancement.
The evaluation indicates that the number of "expired visas" in the US is steady, with no significant increase.
Mr. Wells reported that the total count in the "visa expiration tracking pool" - the tally of individuals whose visas expired post-2010 - stood at 95,432 in the quarter ending September this year, slightly down from 95,789 in the corresponding period two years ago.
The Department contracted with the private firm Global Solutions Inc. to assess and where feasible, resolve the records of individuals with expired visas.
However, Mr. Wells pointed out that there were "considerable errors" in how Global Solutions categorized visa expiration records.
The audit revealed that out of a random sample of 80 records, 22 inaccurately noted that the individual had exited the US.
A spokeswoman for Global Solutions denied allegations that it misused information about travelers to the US and mistyped visa documentation.
She further dismissed "any suggestion that our practices financially benefited us" from the processes applied to log entries and exits of travelers in the US.
In his report, Mr. Wells highlighted that due to what he calls significant errors by Global Solutions, the number of "expired visas" presumed to have left may have been overstated by roughly 2,000 for the fiscal year 2014-15.
Mr. Wells commented, "I was disheartened to find a significant error rate in the classification of visa expiration records, with nearly one-third of departures in my examination being misrepresented.
"Significant enhancements in the Department's ability to track, manage, and prioritize the border control workload will be essential to execute its plan for reducing unlawful stays."
He observed that inspectors had also identified another 140,000 records of individuals without legal residency status in the US, with cases dating back to before 2010.
Lisa Fortwright stated that the suggestions from the report would be actioned, acknowledging that past reforms had started showing beneficial effects and should be evaluated over a period.
"We are committed to rigorous oversight on this matter," she remarked.

The Lakeside Dental Clinic in Brecon will shut its doors on April 30th, and there is no alternative public dental service in the vicinity.
The representative for the public clinic mentioned that despite efforts, they haven't been able to secure a full-time resident dentist for over eighteen months.
The assistant mayor of Brecon, Gwyneth Price, expressed on Radio Wales' Morning Edition that there is a pressing need to incentivize dentists to practice in isolated communities.
Lakeside Dental's head dentist, Dr. Thomas Reed, remarked: "Rural regions in Wales are experiencing a chronic lack of dental practitioners, with continuous vacancies going unfilled for extended durations.
"Despite our attempts to recruit a new dentist for the past one and a half years, we find ourselves in the unfortunate position of discontinuing our operations at the Summit View Dental Centre."
An official from Powys Teaching Health Board disclosed their plan to re-procure dental services in the locality at the earliest opportunity.
"Yet, it is likely that there will be an interim period without service from the cessation of current operations to the finalization of the procurement process and the establishment of successor services," he acknowledged.
"Hence, we are arranging interim measures for dental care provision until we can implement a lasting resolution.
"This involves considering all possible ways to offer interim help from neighboring dental facilities, alongside setting up a temporary dental emergency clinic within Brecon General Hospital to cater to patients with immediate unplanned needs."
A spokesperson for the Welsh Government noted: "Whenever a dental practice scales down or ceases their NHS operations, the funding allocated remains with the local health board for the re-comissioning of services.
"Powys Teaching Health Board is actively seeking bids from dental practices to ensure the continued availability of NHS dental care in the region.
"The health board is expected to persistently assess and enhance the accessibility of NHS primary dental care services, in line with the objectives established in its Operational Plan for the year 2017-18."

Martinez needs to formulate a plan to tackle the high-scoring tactics of the reigning league champions during their upcoming championship semi-final at the National Stadium.
Anticipated to be the most strategic match of the season, Martinez emphasizes that the contest is "entirely focused on the athletes".
"We rely on (the players) to go out and perform," Martinez stated.

"There is, as of now, no cure for tinnitus. We dedicate ourselves to funding research for potential treatments and meanwhile offer resources to those suffering," Kelley explained.

Marcus Peterson, 29, was found guilty of embezzlement last month, in addition to charges of fraud and endangering the public, following a superior court hearing.

Panel judges at the Appellate Division in Bristol overturned his convictions for two major theft charges after defense claims involving the lack of substantive evidence.

He received a five-year sentence for the other crimes.

Defense attorney Laura Smith contested the embezzlement convictions, which hinged on the supposed pattern of dishonest behavior.

This suggested that the proof of one crime was utilized to bolster the other.

Ms. Smith pointed out that there were only two reported incidents, with a considerable lapse in between them of nearly five years.

She noted that the nature of the purported crimes was dissimilar, and there was a lack of "remarkable commonalities."

She contended that for events separated by such an interval, there should be a striking tie, but in this case, there was none.

The prosecution asserted there were striking parallels as both instances involved corporate funds being misused, in the first case by a junior employee and in the second by a mid-level manager.

It also proposed that testimonies from other employees, who witnessed questionable accounting practices, could underpin the convictions.

Justice Stevens, sitting on the appeal with Justices Trent and Hathaway, stated: "A significant passage of time does not necessarily negate the possibility of drawing connections between two acts to suggest a habitual pattern, but it is a factor to consider.

"When the gap is wide, it's essential to scrutinize if the evidence bears any remarkable characteristics that render the connections convincing despite the time lapse.

"The interval here, just under five years, was notable. Thus, for the prosecution to successfully associate the two reported acts, it needed to demonstrate an exceptional element. Such an element was not discernible in this instance."

Peterson had been originally sentenced at the Superior Court in Manchester after a conviction in Liverpool.

The Smithsonian Museum of American History will close its doors this Friday afternoon, and is scheduled to reopen in 2024 after extensive renovations costing several million dollars. This weekend, the museum is hosting various free events including concerts, a community fair, and specialty tours. The facility is currently deemed insufficient for its purposes, requiring updated infrastructure including a new HVAC system. The Smithsonian Museum of American History, located centrally in the National Mall in Washington, D.C., was first inaugurated in 1964. Presently, only about 20% of its vast collection, gifted to the nation by philanthropist James Smithson in 1846, is on display due to the need to preserve sensitive artifacts from environmental stress. The renovations are expected to cost between $70m and $75m. With the renovations, the museum will get energy-saving upgrades such as advanced air filtration systems. Additionally, the renovations will allow for two additional exhibition levels so that up to 95% of the museum’s 10,000 artifacts can be displayed. During the museum's closure, key pieces from its collection will be exhibited at the National Gallery of Art. ‘Smithsonian at the Gallery’ will feature rotating exhibits, ensuring public access to significant historical items. The initial exhibit ‘Smithsonian at the Gallery: American Innovators’ will allow visitors to explore 25 significant inventions by American pioneers. It is set to run from November 1, 2016, until June the following year.
